sen.e: His brother rebuilt the family home but when he committed a crime, his family name was taken; so Ryojiro was implicated and was sent to Oki-no-erabujima Island (according to the description from the Kagoshima Prefectural Library).

sen.e: However, according to another story, when he was working as a scriber for Hisamitsu SHIMAZU, he was found drinking Shochu (distilled spirit) after giving public documents to a pawnbroker to receive money and as a result for that, he was sent to the island (and this is the popular theory).

However, according to another story, when he was working as copyist for Hisamitsu SHIMAZU, he was found that he had been buying shochu (Japanese distilled grain liquor) by putting the public documents in pledge, and sent to Okinoerabu-jima Island (and this is the popular theory).

sen.e: There was also another story which said that in 1862 when Takamori SAIGO was exiled to the same island and was locked in jail in Wadomari-cho town, Kawaguchi moved to the island to teach Saigo's calligraphy and poetry, although he was not a criminal (by Yasutsugu SHIGENO).

sen.e: Because Saigo was busy with national affairs and was not at home mostly, at their house where a man's hand was needed, Kawaguchi was working as a butler to do work around the house such as answering to the visitors and sending and receiving correspondence using his good writing skills and/or Rusuiyaku (a person representing the master during his absence) as well as teaching calligraphy and Chinese poetry to Saigo's young people.

Because Saigo was busy with national affairs and was not at home mostly, his family needed a man who could manage the master's works, therefore Kawaguchi worked as butler to deal with the outside such as attending visitors and using his calligraphy for writing letters, and worked as rusui-yaku (person representing the master during his absence) as well as teaching calligraphy and Chinese literature to Saigo's children.

sen.j: また、西南戦争中に成人男子が出征して西郷家は完全に女所帯となり、武村の屋敷が焼亡した後は鹿児島各地を転々としたが、雪篷は常に一家と苦患をともにし、その精神的支柱となった。
sen.e: After all adult males were out fighting during the Seinan War, Saigo family became a female household; and after the house was burnt down, they were all moving around from place to place in Kagoshima, but Seppo was together with them sharing the sorrows, and gave them emotional support.

sen.e: In the recollection of Mitsuru TOYAMA who visited Kagoshima in 1879, he said, "At Saigo's house, there was a butler around the age of 70, called Seppo KAWAGUCHI who wrote calligraphy and poems" (althought Seppo was 62 at that time), and that when Toyama asked, "I would like to see Father Nanshu" as soon as he got there, Seppo was appalled and told him off by saying "Didn't you know Saigo died in Shiroyama?"

sen.j: 雪蓬、悵然之に謂て曰く『十年役前の鹿児島は、有用の人材輩出せしも、今や、禿山と一般、人才一空、復言ふに忍びざるなり。樹を植ゆるは、百年の計なり。想ふに西郷の如き巨人は、百年又は千年にして一たび出づるもの。而して、斯人再び見る可からず』と。
sen.e: Seppo ruefully said "Kagoshima had many great people before the war but now we only have bald hills and ordinary people, 人才一空, no promise for the future. It takes 100 years to see a tree growing. I think, a titan like Saigo only appearing once in every 100 or 1000 years. So, we will never see anyone like him.

sen.j: 文中の『洗心洞剳記』とは、天保の大飢饉の際に万民の窮状を顧みない大阪奉行所の悪政に敢然と立ち上がった大塩平八郎（中斎）が記した講義録で、西郷に限らず幕末維新の志士の間で愛読されたという。
sen.e: As mentioned above, "Senshin Dosatsuki" was a collection of lecture notes written by Heihachiro OSHIO (Chusai) who stood up against maladministration of Osaka Magistrate Office not considering people's distressed conditions during the Tenpo Famine; and the book was widely read not only by Saigo but also by other supporters of the Restoration at the end of the Edo period.
